Topic.Title: Dell planning shareholder meetings to revise 'the deal'

Message.Msg: "Revised deal" might be for less than the $13.65 previously offered. Evercore has been shopping Dell . The major buyout firms, including KKR, after doing some due dilligence decided not to make an offer. $13.65 per share, $24 billion, is a premium price. Mike Dell and his LBO team don't have to offer so much and may lower their offer to $12.50. Sure Southeastern and T. Rowe Price paid too much for the Dell shares they own, but that's their problem. both those company's should hire some new money managers who won't over pay for stocks .Hope this helps.

Topic.Title: Dell planning shareholder meetings to revise 'the deal'

Message.Msg: ya ya ya. It helps. The sources say special dividend of $1 is most likely. How's that for 'less'.? I've said from the start, $15.50 is the minimum fair amount and my range was 15.50-16.50 as most likely. And frankly, I'm more right by the day. Cover your short position.

Topic.Title: where are the buyout offers?

Message.Msg: You seem more intelligent than the header of your post suggests so I will actually reply. As you know, this isn't about buy-out offers so much as it is about PR and attention to this deal. And Dell et al are getting killed in the PR realm with each penny this rises above their offer. It is as simple as that. And that don't require more than high school ed to figure out. So stop posting stupid comments when your grammar and writing suggest you are smarter than stupid.

Topic.Title: Dell planning shareholder meetings to revise 'the deal'

Message.Msg: This is the best thread on here at this time before 8AM. $15.50-16.50 as I said last week is where this settles. Dell et al cannot railroad this deal through at the current price. And attempting to do so invites public disapprobation (look it up) - a calamity and fodder for the Occupy Wall Street Movement. This is the one time my interests align with those flea-bitten and tick-ridden jackasses. Comg from the likes of me, that tells you this deal is circling down Dante's levels of the Inferno.

Message.Title: Just say No?
Message.Msg: Wouldn't a higher buyout-price increase the chances for deeper job-cuts. Wouldn't DELL then also be less competitive in the market because its products must sell at higher prices for acceptable profit-margins. Should regulators nix buyouts at prices so high that ensuing financial-distress seems likely.

Topic.Title: Just say No?

Message.Msg: sorry ... your conclusions seem to be reasonable but are a bit late .... Where was M.Dell 5 years ago ? now he's got to pay for his own negligence ... and not be rewarded ! Mr.Dell is a problem here !

Topic.Title: Dell planning shareholder meetings to revise 'the deal'

Message.Msg: Bashford - Just being curious, are you short dell or something? I'm honestly curious. What is your motivation for trying to convince people your position? For the record, I'm in for tons of May $14 calls, so I obviously want it to go up. I don't know 100% it's going up. But your first paragraph doesn't make sense. Why would Dell meet with shareholders to say "we are going to offer less?" The fact that they are willing to meet, means that if the large shareholders will agree to something reasonable, they will raise the bid.

Topic.Title: $15 Buyout Price will Likely Happen

Message.Msg: “Best Buy and Dell are losing share fast," says Macke. "They’re worth more private to these guys—Schulze and Dell—than they are in the public market…they’re not going to get a better white knight. In both cases the boards... the shareholders and the big institutions got too cute and now they’re going to lose the entire deal."

Topic.Title: $15 Buyout Price will Likely Happen

Message.Msg: That's it coolstarsky. stock buyers, including institutional buying groups, should understand they are responsible for their actions. If one pays too much for a stock then it is their fault and they may have to take a loss. Simple as that, really.
